various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Big Joe Duskin''' (February 10, 1921 – May 6, 2007){{cite web |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2007.html |accessdate=2010-01-07 |publisher=thedeadrockstarclub.com |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2007 January to June| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20100114223120/http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2007.html| archivedate= 14 January 2010 | deadurl= no}} was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] and [[boogie-woogie]] [[pianist]]. He is best known for his debut [[album]], ''Cincinnati Stomp'' (1978), and the tracks "Well, Well Baby" and "I Met a Girl Named Martha". ==Biography== Born '''Joseph L. Duskin''' in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], by the age of seven he had started playing [[piano]]. He played in church, accompanying his [[preacher]] father, the Rev. Perry Duskin. His family moved to [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]], and Duskin was raised near to the [[Cincinnati Union Terminal|Union Terminal]] [[train station]] where his father worked. On his local [[radio station]], [[WLW]], Duskin heard his hero [[Fats Waller]] play. He was also inspired to play in a boogie-woogie style by [[Pete Johnson]]'s, "627 Stomp".{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 108 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} In his younger days Duskin performed in [[nightclub|clubs]] in Cincinnati and across the river in [[Newport, Kentucky]]. While serving in the [[United States Army|US Army]] in [[World War II]], he continued to play and, in entertaining the [[United States armed forces|US forces]], met his idols Johnson, [[Albert Ammons]] and [[Meade Lux Lewis]]. After his military service ended, Duskin's father made him promise to stop playing while the elder Duskin was still alive. However, Rev. Duskin lived to the age of 105, and Joe found alternative employment as a [[police officer]] and a [[postal worker]]. Therefore Duskin, effectively in the middle of his career, never played a [[keyboard instrument|keyboard]] for sixteen years. With the encouragement of a blues historian, Steven C. Tracy, by the early 1970s Duskin had began playing the piano at [[music festival|festivals]] in the [[United States|US]] and across [[Europe]]. By 1978, and with the reputation for his concert playing now growing, his first recording, ''Cincinnati Stomp'', was released on [[Arhoolie Records]]. The album contained Duskin's [[cover version]] of the track, "[[Down the Road a Piece]]" {{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r54070|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Cincinnati Stomp'' > Overview ))) |accessdate=2010-01-07}} and featured [[Muddy Waters]]' guitarist [[Bob Margolin]]. He subsequently toured both [[Austria]] and [[Germany]], and in 1987 made his inaugural visit to the [[United Kingdom|UK]]. The same year his part in John Jeremy's [[film]], ''Boogie Woogie Special'', recorded for ''[[The South Bank Show]]'', increased Duskin's profile. In 1988, accompanied by the guitar-playing [[Dave Peabody]], Duskin recorded his second album, ''Don't Mess with the Boogie Man''. In the following decade, Duskin performed at both the [[New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival]] and the [[Chicago Blues Festival]]. His touring in Europe continued before he recorded his final album at the Quai du Blues in [[Neuilly]], [[France]]. Several Duskin albums were issued on European labels in the 1980s and 1990s. It was 2004 before ''Big Joe Jumps Again!'' ([[Yellow Dog Records]]) became his second US-based release, and his first studio recording for sixteen years. It featured Phillip Paul (drums), Ed Conley (bass), and [[Peter Frampton]] on guitar.{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p10478/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography by Richard Skelly |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=November 25, 2009}} Duskin was presented with a [[Key to the city#Key to the City|key to the city]] in 2004 by the [[List of mayors of Cincinnati|Mayor of Cincinnati]]. The following year he was awarded a [[National Heritage Fellowship]] by the [[Ohio Arts Council]]. Suffering from the effects of [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], Duskin was on the eve of having legs amputated, when he died in May 2007, at the age of 86.{{cite news |first= |last= |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2007/jun/19/guardianobituaries.obituaries |title=Big Joe Duskin; Bluesman who flourished in later life - obituary by Tony Russell |publisher=Guardian.co.uk |accessdate=November 25, 2009 | location=London | date=June 19, 2007}} The Ohio based [http://www.bigjoeduskin.org Big Joe Duskin Music Education Foundation] keeps his musical ideals alive by producing in-school music presentations for public school children. ==Selected discography== *1978: ''Cincinnati Stomp'' ([[Arhoolie Records|Arhoolie]]) *1988: ''Don't Mess with the Boogie Man'' (Indigo) *1990: ''Down the Road a Piece'' (live album, Wolf) *2004: ''Big Joe Jumps Again! Cincinnati Blues Session'' ([[Yellow Dog Records]]) *2004: ''Live at Quai de Blues'' (live album, [[Virgin Records|Virgin]]){{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p10478/discography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Big Joe Duskin > Discography > Main Albums )))}}{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p10478/discography/compilations|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Big Joe Duskin > Discography > Compilations )))}} ==See also== *[[List of blues musicians]] *[[List of boogie woogie musicians]] *[[List of jazz blues musicians]] ==Quotation== Duskin said in 1987, {{cquote|My dad was a minister, and he was kind of fanatic over religion. When he first knew that I was playing piano, he said 'Don't you never play that devil's music in here. I'll tear you up if I catch you playing that.'..[Years later, his father discovered him playing the blues.]...The old man come in there and jumped on me. Now, when he got done whipping me, I said, 'Pop, you might as well get with it. This is what I want to do.' He looked at me and said, 'Joe, I'm 89 years old. I'm not going to live too long. Why don't you just make an agreement with me not to play the devil's music till I'm dead in the grave?' Well, I shook his hand and I never played a lick. And the old man died at 105."}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bigjoeduskin.org/ Big Joe Duskin website and Foundation] *[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p10478/biography|pure_url=yes}} Biography] at [[Allmusic]] {{Authority control|VIAF=3951877}} {{Persondata | NAME =Duskin, Big Joe | ALTERNATIVE NAMES =Duskin, Joseph L. | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[blues]] and [[boogie-woogie]] pianist | DATE OF BIRTH =February 10, 1921 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Collegeville, Alabama]], United States | DATE OF DEATH =May 6, 2007 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Avondale, Ohio]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Duskin, Big Joe}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American blues pianists]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Alabama]] [[Category:Boogie-woogie pianists]] [[Category:Deaths from diabetes]] [[Category:Jazz-blues pianists]] [[Category:Musicians from Birmingham, Alabama]]
